abstract: Some companies are getting ahead of the due date of their debt by refinancing now, while investors are eager.
snippet: Some companies are getting ahead of the due date of their debt by refinancing now, while investors are eager.
lead_paragraph: A looming wall of debt can be a scary thing. Nearly $830 billion of risky dollar-denominated corporate debt comes due from 2012 to 2014, according to JPMorgan Chase.

headline.main: Chipping Away at the Corporate Debt Wall
headline.print_headline: Chipping Away at the Corporate Debt Wall

byline.original: By AGNES T. CRANE and  ANTONY CURRIE

abstract: An official at JPMorgan Chase said mortgage reductions could reward households for taking on more debt than they could afford and was simply unworkable.
snippet: An official at JPMorgan Chase said mortgage reductions could reward households for taking on more debt than they could afford and was simply unworkable.
lead_paragraph: In a rebuff to the Obama administration, two big banks on Tuesday drew a line in the sand on cutting the mortgage balances of beleaguered homeowners, saying that the tool would be applied sparingly.

headline.main: Banks Resist Plans to Reduce Mortgage Balances
headline.print_headline: Banks Resist Plans to Cut Mortgages

abstract: JPMorgan Chase reported a $3.3 billion profit for its first quarter, a healthy increase over the same time last year as the bank continued to see gains across its businesses, especially in its debt trading.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase reported a $3.3 billion profit for its first quarter, a healthy increase over the same time last year as the bank continued to see gains across its businesses, especially in its debt trading.
lead_paragraph: 7:29 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Eric Dash has more on JPMorgan Chase’s earnings here.

abstract: With the bank’s first-quarter income up 55 percent, its chief raised his outlook on the broader economy.
snippet: With the bank’s first-quarter income up 55 percent, its chief raised his outlook on the broader economy.
lead_paragraph: For big banks, the good news just keeps coming.

headline.main: JPMorgan Upbeat as It Posts Profit

abstract: David Lowman, the mortgage chief at JPMorgan, was mobbed by angry borrowers on Tuesday after he invited customers to speak to him if they feared foreclosure of their homes, Reuters reported.
snippet: David Lowman, the mortgage chief at JPMorgan, was mobbed by angry borrowers on Tuesday after he invited customers to speak to him if they feared foreclosure of their homes, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: David Lowman, the mortgage chief at JPMorgan Chase, was mobbed by angry borrowers on Tuesday after he invited customers to speak to him if they feared foreclosure of their homes, Reuters reported.

headline.main: Angry Borrowers Mob JPMorgan’s Mortgage Chief

abstract: JPMorgan Chase could lose up to $2 billion in revenue if the government clamps down on derivatives trading, Jaime Dimon, its chief executive, said on the bank’s earnings conference call on Wednesday.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase could lose up to $2 billion in revenue if the government clamps down on derivatives trading, Jaime Dimon, its chief executive, said on the bank’s earnings conference call on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase could lose up to $2 billion in revenue if the government clamped down on derivatives trading, Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, told analysts on the bank’s conference call on Wednesday to discuss its first-quarter earnings.

headline.main: Dimon Sees Big Price Tag for Derivatives Rules

abstract: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, took issue with an assertion by Washington Mutual’s former chief executive that WaMu was allowed to fail because it was not part of a government-backed “club” of protected financial institutions.
snippet: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, took issue with an assertion by Washington Mutual’s former chief executive that WaMu was allowed to fail because it was not part of a government-backed “club” of protected financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, took issue with an assertion by Washington Mutual‘s former chief executive, Kerry K. Killinger, that WaMu was allowed to fail because it was not part of a government-backed “club” of protected financial firms that included the big Wall Street banks.

headline.main: Dimon Rebuts Ex-WaMu Chief: Club? What Club?
